A 72-year-old man comes to the office due to 3 days of diarrhea. He began to have nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea 24 hours after eating chicken salad at a fast-food restaurant. The patient continues to have 4-6 episodes of diarrhea per day with no blood in the stool. Temperature is 380 C, blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 88/mm. Abdominal examination reveals mild diffuse tenderness to palpation and increased bowel sounds. Cultures of the stool yield gram-negative bacilli that are non-lactose fermenting and oxidase negative. Which of the following is the most likely complication associated with this patient‘s current infection?

A 40—year-old man came to OPD with the complaint of hemoptysis for 10 days duration. He also has had night sweats but reports no fever or weight loss. Temperature is 37.70C, blood pressure is 118/ 68 mm Hg, pulse is 86/min, and respirations are 18/min. Physicalexamination shows right-sided rhonchi and crackles. Chest x-ray shows an infiltrate in the right upperlobe. Sputum samples from 3 consecutive days are also obtained. After 72 hours of tuberculin skin test placement, there is no induration at the site; however, 2 of 3 sputum sample smears reveal acid-fastbacilli. Which of the following best explains the negative TST in this patient?

A 60-year-old woman with ovarian cancer undergoing chemotherapy is hospitalized due to fever, headache, ataxia, and progressive confusion. Two days later, a 26-year-old pregnant woman is admitted to the same hospital with fever, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and muscle aches and spontaneously delivers a preterm infant who has generalized skin rash. Laboratory evaluation reveals that these patients‘conditions were caused by the same microbial organism which exhibits a typical growth pattern in the semisolid medium as shown in the image. Reports of similar illnesses are noted in neighbouring cities. A subsequent investigation reveals that 8 people were affected, all of whom consumed food products from a single processing facility. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this outbreak?

A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents due to intense perianal. itching, especially during the night. The patient is otherwise healthy and her development has been normal. He was trying to retrieve a cricket ball that had rolled under a log when he got stung by something. By the time he told his mom, his body was covered in welts. His mother gave him diphenhydramine. but the patient's face started to swell and he was having a hard time swallowing. The patients blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg, and heart rate is 120/min. Physical examination shows erythematous. raised plaques over the trunk, extremities, and face. Lung auscultation reveals bilateral expiratory wheezes. The mother is not aware of the child having any similar reaction in the past. Which of the following most likely triggered this patient’s condition?

options.label: D
options.text: Cell surface-bound antibody bridging by antigen

questions.correct_answer: D. Cell surface-bound antibody bridging by antigen

Her temperature is 38.1°C, blood pressure is 126/78 mmHg, pulse is 94/min, and respirations are 16/min. Physical examination reveals suprapubic tenderness to palpation and a normal bimanual exam. Hemogram is normal except Eosinophils(12.5%). Urinalysis microscopy shown in the image. What is the infective stage of this pathogen?

On examination, the doctor noted vision to be only Perception of light present. There was scleral perforation in nasal part of eye with uveal tissue show. What is not done in such a scenario?

A 27 year old man is brought to the emergency department unconscious after a motor vehicle accident. The patient was texting on the cell phone & was not wearing a helmet during the accident. He has no known medical problems & takes no medications. His temperature is 36.7*C, blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg, pulse is 60/min & respiratory rate is 12/min. A linear fracture of skull at the junction of frontal, parietal, temporal & sphenoid bone is seen on head CT scan. A branch of which artery is severed in this patient ?
True/False rearding carotid sheath:

options.label: A
options.text: Ansa cervicalis lies on the posterior wall of carotid sheath

options.label: B
options.text: Carotid sheath is formed by all three layers of deep cervical fascia

options.label: C
options.text: Carotid sheath contains IX, X and XI cranial nerves in whole extent.

options.label: D
options.text: Sympathetic chain lies in between Internal carotid arteries and internal jugular vein

options.label: E
options.text: CCA divided at the lower level of thyroid cartilage

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • • Ansa cervicalis lies on the Anterior wall of carotid sheath
  • • • Carotid sheath contains only X cranial nervein whole extent.
  • • • Sympathetic chain lies posterior to carotid sheath
  • • • CCA divided at the upper level of thyroid cartilage

questions.text: A 77-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after he was found unresponsive at home. The patient has a history of poorly controlled hypertension. Blood pressure is 260/140 mm Hg and pulse is 108/min He has extensor posturing and pinpoint pupils. CT scan of the head without contrast reveals an acute pontine hemorrhage with associated mass effect. The patient dies several hours later. Autopsy reveals disruption of all pigmented neurons in the posterior rostral pons at the lateral floor of the fourth ventricle. These neurons normally produce which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • This patient had a hypertensive hemorrhage in the pons at the level of the locus ceruleus. a paired pigmented brainstem nucleus located in the posterior rostral pons near the lateral floor of the fourth ventricle The locus ceruleus functions as the principal site for norepinephrine synthesis in the brain and projects to virtually all parts of the central nervous system. It is involved in the control of mood, arousal (reticular activating system), sleep-wake states, cognition, and autonomic function (eg, blood pressure control). Abnormal activation of the locus ceruleus has been implicated in the pathogenesis of anxiety disorders (eg, panic attacks).
  • • Patients with bilateral pontine hemorrhage typically present with coma due to disruption of the reticular activating system. Other features usually include total paralysis with extensor posturing due to corticospinal and corticobulbar tract injury and pinpoint pupils secondary to descending sympathetic tract damage.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the clinicdue to firm, nontenderswelling of her right cheek for the past 4 months. The patient has had no fever,runny nose, sore throat, or cough.
